docs.lead_paragraph: Once, sex addicts were treated with pillories and guillotines and gleaming clamps, but what used to be a moral problem is now a medical one, and this is no surprise. Our understanding of sexual compulsion has followed the same trajectory as our understanding of melancholy and moodiness. It's all in the brain. Goodbye heart, goodbye groin, and voil rumpled, slick organ crammed in its sheath of skull. New scientific theories are shedding an interesting light on the biochemistry of perversion and maybe, by extension, on the chemistry of ordinary kinkiness -- what you and I do, volitionally and consensually, behind bedroom doors. His name, in all seriousness, is Dr. Kafka. No relation, he says. Martin Kafka treats and studies paraphiliacs at McLean Hospital in Belmont, Mass. Paraphilias are disorders characterized by persistent deviant sexual arousal -- think exhibitionism, fetishism and pedophilia. Closely related to the paraphilias are what Kafka calls the paraphilia-related disorders (P.R.D.'s). Those suffering from P.R.D.'s are, in common vernacular, sex addicts, who may not be breaking the law but are driven by libidos so excessive that they are pinned beneath their weight.

headline.main: How Do You Cure A Sex Addict?

docs.abstract: Lauren Slater reports on sex addiction, and its treatment; comments on work of Dr Martin Kafka, psychiatrist who treats and studies paraphiliacs at McLean Hospital in Belmont, Mass; comments on inverse relationships between eating disorders and sexual impulse disorders; Kafka's treatment of sexual-impulse disorders chemically discussed; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: A half-moon hung low over Miami at 1 a.m. on Election Day, and the air was thick with possibility. Vice President Al Gore had drawn a large crowd, most of it in tight jeans, to the sands of South Beach for the final rally of his two-year campaign. Embraced by celebrities like Stevie Wonder and Robert De Niro, he was clearly moved, and encouraged. ''We're going to carry Florida!'' he vowed in an arm-pumping speech. ''We're going to win the White House!'' Eight months earlier, when Mr. Gore and Gov. George W. Bush of Texas had just secured their parties' nominations, such an assertion would have been considered audacious. Florida, many assumed, was unassailable Republican territory, won by Democrats only three times in 40 years. Two-thirds of its Congressional delegation was Republican, as were both houses of its State Legislature. And the popular governor happened to be the younger brother of the Republican nominee.

headline.main: How Florida Got Close Enough to Fight Over

docs.abstract: Demographic changes and strategic choices transformed Florida into very crucible of 2000 campaign, state both presidential candidates decided they had to win; although Gov George W Bush had institutional advantages in state, turnout was immense among black voters, 93 percent of whom support Vice Pres Al Gore; Gore also piled up 60 percent majority in three southeast Florida counties, Broward, Miami-Dade and Palm Beach, with help from his running mate, Sen Joseph I Lieberman, who enthralled Jewish Democratic stalwarts there; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The uneven quality of American health care is easy to complain about but hard to fix. This week a group of 60 large corporations, the Leapfrog Group, announced a bold start. Members, including General Motors, General Electric and I.B.M., pledged to steer employees to hospitals that did the best job treating patients. That may seem an obvious strategy. But naming names -- in effect labeling some hospitals good and others bad -- is a difficult task that few employers relish. Yet it may be the single most effective weapon against sloppy medical care. The Leapfrog initiative follows publication of a report last year from the Institute of Medicine of the National Academy of Sciences that showed as many as 100,000 patients die in hospitals each year because of medical mistakes. An even larger number, perhaps 3 percent of all hospitalized patients, suffer injuries from treatment. The basic problem, the report said, is the absence of safety systems that catch doctors' mistakes before they harm patients.
